The Prime Minister, on behalf of the War Cabinet,King. extended a warm welcome to thePrime Minister of Canada. he hoped that he would stay as long as possible, and would take thefullest possible part in their deliberations, and would also attend meetings' of the Defence Committee (Operations). The whole country had the greatest admiration for the war effort made by canada under Mr. Mackenzie King's leadership.Mr. Mackenzie King thanked the Prime Minister for hiswelcome and said that the object of his visit was to find out whether there was any way in which Canada could make her war effort more effective. Canada was heart and soul with Great Britain in thisstruggle and had the greatest admiration for the British people and for the way in which this citadel of freedom had been maintained. Nothing could be more cordial than the relationsbetween Canada and Great Britain, or between their fightingservices.Naval, Militaryand air operations.(previous reference:W.M. The French embassy had complained that 6 people had been killed at Lille, and 80 at brest.The Prime Minister said that the Vichy Government had notcomplained of our bombing military objectives in Occupied France.He thought it would be desirable that a distinction should bedrawn between the latitude given to our bombers when bombingtargets in Occupied France as compared with the instructions givento them when bombing targets in Germany.The War Cabinet invited the Secretary of State for air to consider whether further instructions should be issued on the lines suggested." The War Cabinet had before them a Memorandum by theHome Secretary submitting for their information the facts andconsiderations about the control of the border between NorthernIreland and Eire (W.P. (41) 192).The Home Secretary said that he had brought this matter before the War Cabinet because there was some parliamentary criticism urging that far more stringent measures of control shouldbe introduced. For the reasons set out in his Paper, he had reachedthe conclusion that, broadly, the present system should be main-tained, subject to various minor points mentioned in his Paper.The War Cabinet expressed agreement with this view.U.S.S.R. 7. The War Cabinet had before them a Memorandum by the preparations Home Secretary and Minister of Home Security covering Depart-for next mental Reports on preparations to meet heavy air attacks nextwhiter. winter (W.P. (G) (41) 77).The Home Secretary and Minister of Home Security said thatthe Departments had submitted valuable Reports, and much goodpreparatory work had been done. He proposed to ask for further progress Reports later on, while monthly Reports from regional commissioners would be considered by the Civil Defence Committee.The main difficulty now being experienced was in regard to shortage of materiel and labour for the manufacture of equipment and appliances.In reply to a question, the Home Secretary and Minister ofHome Security agreed that in certain areas, particularly thosewhich had not experienced heavy air attack, local authorities were rather slow to respond. Additional powers had, however, beentaken, by which he (the Minister) or the Regional Commissionerscould give specific directions to local authorities.The War Cabinet took note of the Memorandum by theHome Secretary and Minister of Home Security.Great George Street, S.
